title: Gothic compressed used for "The Place Beyond The Pines" movie title sequence
content:
Would like some help to find THE match for this one. It's close to Heroic Condensed but that's not it (/G, /R).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317065751im_/http:/typophile.com/files/pbtp-dc-01_5148.jpg)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317065751im_/http:/typophile.com/files/pbtp-dc-05_6549.jpg)

More here: [http://annyas.com/screenshots/updates/place-beyond-the-pines-2012-ryan-g...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317065751/http:/annyas.com/screenshots/updates/place-beyond-the-pines-2012-ryan-gosling/ "http://annyas.com/screenshots/updates/place-beyond-the-pines-2012-ryan-gosling/")

Font: 

 Chalet Comprimé 

Solved By: 

 [DPape](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317065751/http:/typophile.com/user/3945 "View user profile.")
author: Ryuk

comments.content: Thanks Don. Dick told me it could be Chalet Comprimé which is the closest I got so far. The only differences I could see is on /R leg terminal, Chalet's is slightly curved and TPBTP's not which I assume could be due to LD quality sample.

Actually, after a closer inspection, there's a neon/rounded effect applied which could explain this small lost.  
I finally found an irrefutable proof it should be Chalet Comprimé (or at least Chalet slightly customized), this /, can't lie. Case solved.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317065751im_/http:/typophile.com/files/tpbtp01_6395.png)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317065751im_/http:/typophile.com/files/tpbtp02_5623.png)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317065751im_/http:/typophile.com/files/tpbtp03_4911.png)
Yeah, it is too bad that Dick Pape was 'run off' from Typrophile for being IMHO too good at identifying fonts. Apparently this Font ID section is only for purchasable fonts.
